addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie

26 June 1589 From M
r
Thomas Bodley
Secret instructions sent to
Barnevelt.
his use of them
A message deliv
r
d to
e
Counsel of state
and sent herew
th
.
His stomacke against her
Ma
tie
and this nation.
His [strainable] and cruel course holden against.
The D [evil] offers direction desireth sucesse of
skink
&
Count william.
45

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 June 26
It may please yo
r
H. there are letters come hi-
ther from
e Deputies in
England,
w
t
many secret
informac
o
ns to Barnevelt, whiche have putt him
more out of temper, then he was at any time of late.
The particularities I can not understand: but
e
Generall states
assembled uppon it, and Barnevelt
from them delivered that message to
e
Councell of
state
, wherof I send yo
r
H.
e copie, as it is sette
downe in o
r
register booke. In effect it is fitt
at
yo
r
H. doe knowe,
at all his maner and action in do-
ing
e message, savoured mervelously of stomacke, con-
tempt, and revenge, in respect, as it seemed, of some
thing written from
e Deputies, and as yo
r
H. may
see, for
at
e supernumeraries are c
o
tinued in
e
Garrison of
Flushing
.
Whiche he maketh
e occasion of
e losse of their townes.
Because I knowe his crueltie
and bitternes, howe litle he respecteth her Ma
ties
favo
r
,
and howe muche
e rest of that assemblie are gover-
ned by him, I doe almost assure my self,
at the
poore felowe wilbe putte to
e torture
, and proceeded
against w
t
all extremitie, as in
crimine liese Ma
tis
.
He hath bin already examined in my presence uppon
e
pointes of his letter, and hath bin charged further, uppon
e losse of
Sluce,
to have called
e states traito
r
s, to have
cried out in Flushing, at suche time as
e states were
there together, or
il est temps Bourgeois, il est temps,
and to have uttered other traiterous speeches against the
state, w
ch
he doth utterly denie, and I can not yet per-
ceave
at they can justifie. His letter is their chiefest
accusation, whiche he striveth to interpret to
e best for
himself, alleaging
at those were suche reportes, as were
commonly then abroade, as no dout they were, and these
men knowe well enough,
and
in that respect might have
charged him rather w
t
a seditious, then a traiterous
practise. But
e endevo
r
of some is no other in this
place, but to have it notified to all
e world, that it is
e Englishe nation, and not they, that offer all
e occa-
sion of disunion in these contreis:
and to make a shewe
that it is so, they catche at all advantages in any thing,
be
e persons or
eir actions never so simple.
fol.309v
I am also privatly informed,
at Barnevelt com-
plaineth,
at
Sonoye,
and
e rest w
t
him in England,
finde a more favorable audience and accesse then their
deputies, and
at their affaires of importance are dal-
lied w
t
all, and suche troblesome causes preferred.
Wheruppon in his heat he hath given it out, that they shall
be forced to seeke no more to her Ma
tie
but to defende
themselves against
e Ennemie, w
t
suche meanes as
ei
have. And if other successe then good come of it ether
to
e Contrey or to her Ma
tie
e blame to be cast uppon
her Hig
nes
. By these and other tokens I perceave that
e Deputies being in England, hath done more hurt then
good.
For before those last letters of theirs came, we
were in a very good way, to come to good correspon-
dence.
As I have made
e motion heereto-
fore, if it might stand w
t
yo
r
H. pleasure, to affourde
me some
times some
litle
direction,
it would be a speciall
helpe to
e advauncement of
e service, in the place where
I am trusted. For
whether
it be her Ma
ties
meaning, as it
seemeth sometimes, not to leave these contreis unpro-
tected, howsoever in their rudenes they deale un-
worthely w
t
her: or whether she be resolved, if they will
not come to reason, to seeke her securitie, by some other
kinde of
course,
because I knowe it not, and because I
see some
actions sometimes bende one way, and others at
an other time repugnant, it is a very great hindrance
to
e uniforme proceeding, w
ch
we that are heere,
must of necessitie keepe, to
doe
any good. whiche I am
bothe to signifie, and to beseeche yo
r
H. in respect of
making me more able to discharge my duty, to give
me
nowe and then some
further light of her Ma
ties
intentions
: whiche I referre notw
t
standing to yo
r
H. wisdome and good liking. This
day we receaved a letter from S
r
Martin Schincke,
wherein he writeth
at
e 22 of this moneth sty
l
ve
t
he encountered w
t
e Ennemies forces at
Santen
in Cleveland
be-
yonde
e river of Rhine, w
ch
he passed at
Bislike,
and after 6 houres c
o
flict putt them to flight, and
slewe, as he himself writeth a 1000 but as it is cer-
tified from an other but 400. Of o
r
s were slaine
58 and 124 hurt: of w
ch
there were missed but 5 Englishe
fol.310r
Besides
e fort of
Fernsume,
whiche I signified in
my last to be surprised by Count William in
West-
Frise
, we have advertism
t
sins, that he hath also
taken
Reyde
a place of greater improtance, and an
other fort by
Woldendorp,
uppon
e same coast all
three: wheruppon there is hope conceaved of bringing
at contrey to contribution, and of cutting of
e pas-
sage of victuall to
Groeninghen.
The
Ennemie hath attempted of late to enter
e Isle of
Williamstat,
where he presented himself w
t
a 1000
footemen, and 2 cornets of horse: but finding the
pesants uppon
e bancks ready to make resistance,
retired w
t
out doing any thing.
And thus I take
my humble leave, beseching yo
r
H. if there be any
thing in this letter, to impart it w
t
my L. Treasuro
r
.
From
e Hage June 26 1589.
Yo
r
H most humbly bounden Thomas Bodley
It may please yo
r
H.
at
e
sending of
e Extract inclosed
may not come to
e knowledge
of
e Deputies, lest it prove an
occasion, whereby they may seeke
to barre us of
e meanes, to come
to
e knowledge of their proceedinges
hereafter.
